utterances: So I think what happens with the jurors now is, and with the public is, listen guys, I know people who have been hurt by this and there's no way you guys are going to get away with it.
And on that point, Nat, it might be worth pointing out that these guys were not just big wigs in the corporate sector, but Ken Lay was a big donor to President Bush.
He donated some $300,000 to his two gubernatorial campaigns, to the then gubernatorial campaigns, and $100,000 to his 2000 presidential race.
He's somebody that Bush once called Kenny Boy.
Not only are they politically active in town, in particular Lay, but they're also very active in civic affairs.
Lay gave millions of dollars to many civic causes.
And a la Richard Scrushy in HealthSouth, I think that he thought that that was going to say, hey I'm this big guy in town.
I've helped you in the community, but the community turned on him.
And it's good note to save any delays, September will be the reckoning day as relates to sentencing, but that may, in fact, be pushed back.
All right, Donald Rumsfeld took to the airwaves last night on Larry King as he did an extensive interview with Larry King.
He talked about that a timetable to exit Iraq would not do any good.
He also talked about the strength of the U.S.
military; but that he was in fact surprised at the strength of the insurgents in Iraq and that there were no weapons of mass destruction.
Blaming that on imperfect intelligence.

This juxtaposed to a report released by the Congressional and Defense Department officials that suggest an official military investigation into allegations that American Marines killed innocent Iraqis last November has uncovered evidence that a number of dead civilians is much higher than the 15 originally reported.
Larry King also talked about Guantanamo, where Donald Rumsfeld suggested that everything was fine and dandy there.
There are going to be those, Laura Washington, who suggest that this interview is part and parcel of the problem.
It's the emperor has no clothes once again.
Well, it's no accident that this interview was done with Larry King.
With all due respect, he's not the most insightful interviewer in the world and he tends to treat all of his guests like celebrities.
And, of course, Rumsfeld got the celebrity treatment and allowed him to give us still another snow job.
It's clear that this is a tactical strategy on their part.
I don't think it's working.
It's what I called - what they created around the White House is a culture of implausible deniability.
I mean they want to deny, they want to say that everything is okay, but they just are not believable.
It's completely implausible to say that whether the intelligence was perfect or not, that you didn't have - you should've been in possession of enough information to make some intelligent decisions.
He was surprised by the insurgency?
There were plenty of folks predicting this even before we went into Iraq.
So he definitely has no clothes.

And then when you look at some of the things that are happening on an ongoing basis right now - some of these investigations you mentioned - and the fact that they aren't even addressing these issues.
Again, it's completely erodes their credibility.
Hey, Joe, we don't want to give short shrift to the investigation in the sense of the name William Calley comes to mind.
And we know what that became.
When you talk about killing women and children included within this alleged massacre, it can become very problematic to the military.
Well, there's absolutely no question about that.
And I think, if I recall correctly from one report I heard, that one child was 3-years-old.
If this becomes the Bush administration's My Lai - you mentioned Lt.
Calley, and, of course, that's what he's associated with in the Vietnam War, which was a critical turning point, I think, for many Americans in that view of that war.

If this becomes that, well, then the perception of the war can only fall further, and it's already - we're already talking about a Bush administration that has ratings in the 30 percent range, in terms of approval ratings.
And I think the strategy to try to generate support for the war is at an interesting crossroads for the Bush administration.

Last night in his televised press conference with Prime Minister Blair, it was interesting the way they acknowledged some missteps, some mistakes, if you will, after having this kind of bravado front for so long.
It was clearly a different approach.
I'm not sure at all that it's going to help win back support for the war that has dropped drastically over the past couple of years.
Well, you know, Joe, I agree with you.
I watched that press conference last night and I thought as we do, as Americans everywhere, began to reflect on this Memorial weekend.
That America itself and its view of this war has already reached a turning point.

And I think that the recent revelations about the number of Iraqis killed in this - possibly by the Marines, that this is, as President Bush acknowledged -he said that one of his three or four mistakes that he was ready to acknowledge - he said so far what happened in the Abu Gharib prison was one that he thought that we were paying a terrible price for.
And I think, should it turn out that in fact these Marines have killed innocent civilians, Iraqi civilians, it will also be something that will stain our presence in Iraq.
Allright.
We're going to take a break, come back in just a second.
Happy birthday to the man known as the Picasso of jazz, Miles Davis, and Kind of Blue.
And what happens when a star loses his 15 minutes of fame?
We'll tell you what happened with one star when the spotlight dimmed.
And I think that as we - we're not even talking about the fact that we're spending $9 billion a month any longer.
That's not the problem.
The fact that we may be approaching something like 3,000 dead Americans is not the problem.
But I think it's more of the fact that we have now - the future of our involvement in Iraq is left to the prime minister, the newly elected prime minister of Iraq.
How did we get ourselves in this position?

Laura, Rumsfeld suggested a timetable won't do any good, but there's a looming date that may make all of this moot, in the sense of pressure put on the White House and that, of course, is the '06 midterm election.
Absolutely.
November.
And I think it's going to be one of two ways.
Either the administration is going to get with it and decide that they got to send a clear message, timetable, something, that has an end date or has some hope for us getting out in the near future.
They have to make that announcement before November, or it's going to get made for them in terms of the - given what we were just talking about - about their low ratings in the polls.
A lot of folks are going to go down in Congress, Republicans, because of this and then it'll get made by whoever's left standing.

I think what happens in a situation like that in Washington, if, in fact, you see some of the House and Senate being blown away by the peripheral issues here on the war and they are going to look to the White House for blame, what happens in a situation like that?
Well, I think what you see happening already is you see Republican candidates, in some cases, not wanting the president to campaign for them openly.
They might allow him to come in and raise money in a closed-door session, but they start putting distance between themselves - their candidacies and the Bush administration.
So it becomes Bush's albatross?
Exactly.
And I think that's what it has become.
And you find many Republicans who are critical of the president not always from the same perspective as Democrats, but they do have a lot of criticism for this president.
And not only for the war, but for spending measures.
A lot of Republicans think, for example, that - they're curious as to why he has not vetoed any spending measure as of yet.
And so you find a lot of Republicans looking at his poll ratings, as I said earlier are in the 30s, and they're realizing that this might not be the guy I want standing next to me at my next rally.

We should note, Nat, that Congressman Murtha, who made a name for himself a few months back in talking about the problems and how problematic this war has become, suggested after hearing all of what the White House has said over the course of the last 48 hours that we simply cannot sustain this operation.
Yeah.
And I think that Murtha is the one voice for both Republicans and Democrats.
I think Murtha has become the voice of midstream Middle America - just every day common Americans - when he says, look, folks, we went in there with good intentions.
We had bad information.
We're there.
We had good intentions, but now we're part of the problem.

And I think one of the ways that we may get a true production out of this is that the new prime minister will privately advocate for a reduction of troops and that he will take the lead in this and suggest that the Iraqis are asking the Americans to withdraw.
And that may be the face-saving measure that the president needs.
After all, this is moved away almost, in some respects, as Joe pointed out, from being America's war to being Blair and Bush's war; that they were the two guys that did this.
Let me get this in very quickly before we run out of time.
Taylor, load this up for me.
Here's a song made popular by the very popular rapper, 50 Cent.
(Soundbite of song "Just a Lil' Bit")
Mr.
50 CENT (Rapper): (Singing) I ain't tryna beef, I'm tryna get my drink on.
Got my diamonds, my fitted, and my mink on.
I'ma kick it at the bar till its time to go, then I'ma get shorty here and I'ma let her know.
Alright.
That's Just a Little Bit, 50 Cent.
Got to get his drink on.
We should note that 50 was honored with the very prestigious Songwriter of the Year award from the authors and publishers of the pop music award and ASCAP/BMI.
Here's what's interesting.

Those of us who - and I should note that I'm not a big hip hop fan, though I do own some 50 Cent - but it's hard for a guy who grew up on Smokey Robinson and Bill Withers and Marvin Gaye, to listen to some of the lyrical content in a 50 Cent song and wonder why you're winning songwriter of the year.
Because he also won it for Candy Shop and a number of other songs.
And if you knew what Candy Shop - and here's the interesting point - if parents knew what Candy Shop was really talking about, many of them wouldn't walk around singing it, Laura Washington.
Well, parents should know and if they don't, you know, shame on them.
I think, you know, I agree with you, 50 Cent is not on the top of my list of performers.
But, you know, creativity and quality is in the eye and ear of the beholder.
And the young folks today, this is what they want to hear.
This is what is making money for the record producers and for people like 50 Cent.
And I think it really comes down to that.
It's not about creativity, in terms of these awards, it's who has the market influence.
But we should note, Joe, that this was voted on by 700 songwriters.
So this is an industry award.
Yeah, that's true and I agree with you, Ed.
I mean, we're both from Detroit, and, like you said, Smokey Robinson, Marvin Gaye.
I mean, compare What's Going On to Candy Shop.
I mean it's - to me, I don't understand it.
But I will say, though, that in preparation for this, I went out and read the lyrics of some of his songs.
While some of them rub me the wrong way, there's also a certain poignancy in some of these lyrics that speaks to kind of really the devastating situation of young, black men.
I've got to give him his props for that, even, if overall, I don't think I would've voted for him.
I know I would not have.
Nat, real quick for me.
I was with Laura.
I looked up the lyrics for Candy Shop and I just couldn't believe it.
To imagine that adults are walking around singing that, it's just beyond comprehension.
I mean, just speechless.
Let me say this: I didn't have to look up the lyric, because I knew it.
So maybe that speaks to me.
All right, folks, thanks very much.
Great to --
Every discussion goes around it.
Well, we just had a problem with the car - but it's one of those things where, well, let's not do it.
Let's wait until the condo sells and then we can have the car fixed.
You know, I think about my IRAs or my 401Ks and do I have to break into those.
Many economists right now don't predict a serious housing crash.
Rather, they say the overheated market just had to cool.
But...
There are two wild cards this time around.
William Wheaton is an economics professor at MIT.
First, he's concerned that interest rates will keep going up and all the people on adjustable rate loans will be forced to sell as their payments go up.
He's also worried that a lot of people who bought investment or second homes recently could get spooked and sell them.
